motor.text: Can hold head up and begins to push up when lying on tummy
Makes smoother movements with arms and legs

social.text: Begins to smile at people
Can briefly calm self (may bring hands to mouth)
Tries to look at parent

cognitive.text: Pays attention to faces
Begins to follow things with eyes
Begins to act bored (cries, fussy) if activity doesn't change

motor.text: Pushes down on legs when feet are on a hard surface
May be able to roll over from tummy to back

language.text: Babbles with expression and copies sounds heard
Cries in different ways to show hunger, pain, or being tired

social.text: Smiles spontaneously, especially at people
Likes to play with people and might cry when playing stops
Copies some movements and facial expressions

cognitive.text: Lets you know if happy or sad
Responds to affection
Reaches for toy with one hand
Uses hands and eyes together, such as seeing a toy and reaching for it

motor.text: Rolls over in both directions (front to back, back to front)
Rocks back and forth on hands and knees

language.text: Responds to sounds by making sounds
Strings vowels together when babbling and likes taking turns with parent while making sounds
Begins to say consonant sounds (m, b)

social.text: Knows familiar faces and begins to know if someone is a stranger
Likes to play with others, especially parents
Responds to other people's emotions and often seems happy
Likes to look at self in a mirror

cognitive.text: Looks at things nearby
Brings things to mouth
Shows curiosity about things and tries to get things that are out of reach
Begins to pass things from one hand to the other

language.text: Makes a lot of different sounds like "mamamama" and "bababababa"
Copies sounds and gestures of others

social.text: May be afraid of strangers
May be clingy with familiar adults
Has favorite toys

cognitive.text: Watches the path of something as it falls
Looks for things seen hidden
Plays peek-a-boo
Puts things in mouth
Moves things smoothly from one hand to the other

motor.text: Gets to a sitting position without help
Pulls up to stand, walks holding on to furniture
May take a few steps without holding on

language.text: Uses simple gestures, like shaking head "no" or waving "bye-bye"
Tries to say words you say

social.text: Is shy or nervous with strangers
Cries when mom or dad leaves
Has favorite things and people
Hands you a book when wants to hear a story

cognitive.text: Explores things in different ways, like shaking, banging, throwing
Finds hidden things easily
Looks at the right picture or thing when it's named
Copies gestures
Starts to use things correctly (drinks from a cup, brushes hair)

language.text: Points to show someone what they want

social.text: Copies what others are doing
Shows you an object they like
Claps when excited
Hugs stuffed dolls or other toys

cognitive.text: Knows what ordinary things are for (phone, brush, spoon)
Points to get the attention of others
Shows interest in a doll or stuffed animal by pretending to feed

motor.text: May walk up steps and run
Drinks from a cup and eats with a spoon

language.text: Points to show someone what they want

social.text: May have temper tantrums
May be afraid of strangers
Shows affection to familiar people
Plays simple pretend, such as feeding a doll

cognitive.text: Knows what ordinary things are for (phone, brush, spoon)
Points to get the attention of others
Shows interest in a doll or stuffed animal by pretending to feed
Points to one body part
Scribbles on own

motor.text: Climbs onto and down from furniture without help
Walks up and down stairs holding on

language.text: Points to things or pictures when they are named
Points to things in a book

social.text: Copies others, especially adults and older children
Gets excited when with other children
Shows more and more independence
Plays mainly beside other children, but begins to include them in activities

cognitive.text: Finds things even when hidden under two or three covers
Begins to sort shapes and colors
Completes sentences and rhymes in familiar books
Plays simple make-believe games
Builds towers of 4 or more blocks
Might use one hand more than the other
Follows two-step instructions such as "Pick up your shoes and put them in the closet"

motor.text: Walks up and down stairs, one foot on each step

language.text: Says first name, age, and sex
Says words like "I," "me," "we," and "you" and some plurals

social.text: Copies adults and friends
Shows affection for friends without prompting
Takes turns in games
Shows concern for a crying friend
Understands the idea of "mine" and "his" or "hers"
Shows a wide range of emotions

cognitive.text: Can work toys with buttons, levers, and moving parts
Plays make-believe with dolls, animals, and people
Does puzzles with 3 or 4 pieces
Understands what "two" means
Copies a circle with pencil or crayon
Turns book pages one at a time
Screws and unscrews jar lids or turns door handle

motor.text: Hops and stands on one foot up to 2 seconds
Catches a bounced ball most of the time
Pours, cuts with supervision, and mashes own food

language.text: Knows some basic rules of grammar, such as correctly using "he" and "she"
Sings a song or says a poem from memory
Can say first and last name

social.text: Enjoys doing new things
Plays "Mom" and "Dad"
Is more and more creative with make-believe play
Would rather play with other children than alone
Cooperates with other children
Often can't tell what's real and what's make-believe

cognitive.text: Names some colors and some numbers
Understands the idea of counting
Starts to understand time
Remembers parts of a story
Understands the idea of "same" and "different"
Draws a person with 2 to 4 body parts
Uses scissors
Starts to copy some capital letters
Plays board or card games

motor.text: Stands on one foot for 10 seconds or longer
Hops; may be able to skip
Uses a fork and spoon and sometimes a table knife
Can use the toilet on own

language.text: Tells a simple story using full sentences
Uses future tense; for example, "Grandma will be here"

social.text: Wants to please friends
Wants to be like friends
More likely to agree with rules
Likes to sing, dance, and act
Is aware of gender
Can tell what's real and what's make-believe
Shows more independence

cognitive.text: Counts 10 or more things
Can draw a person with at least 6 body parts
Can print some letters or numbers
Copies a triangle and other geometric shapes
Knows about things used every day, like money and food
